review_title: Do your homework before joining BLC.  Some good jobs; some bad.
pros: A faith based organization with over 100 years of history with outstanding direct service providers and beautiful people to support.  In some locations, for some managers, this could be a dream job helping people.  In other locations and departments, you could spend your time banging your head against the proverbial brick wall.  Read all of these reviews.  I've seen the good and the bad.  Depending where you work and who you work for, any of these reviews might describe what you will get.  My first 6 months, I'd give it 4 to 5 star rating.  My last 6 months, maybe 1 or 2.  It went from being one of the best places I worked to one of the worst.
cons: Look at BLC's 1099 forms and public disclosures, the cash flow situation is rough.  The regulatory and funding environment of this industry has changed; BLC did not know how to change with it and is now trying to fit a decade or 2 of transition into a couple of years.  The current organization culture is a mixture of toxic micromanagement or good empowering management depending on your location and department and boss.  There is a mixture of people willing to try new things and adopt best practices and others that do not want any form of change.  !!!Be sure to talk to a number of staff members in the location or department you are considering taking a job with!!!  Also, look closely at the benefits.  If you come from a competitor in the field, they'll be comparable.  If you come from a tech, manufacturing, or academic environment, they'll be poor.  Note the retirement contributions have a vesting period and that there are no paid holidays. (I.e. if you want Christmas off, it will take a vacation day.)  More than one person I know found this out AFTER they took the job because it was not explained clearly beforehand.

job_title: Direct Support Professional/Job Coach in Portland, OR
pros:
-Wonderful clients
-Getting to help people
-Some supportive coworkers
cons:
When I was hired in 2012 I unknowingly walked into an all-out battle between management and some workers who were trying to unionize. I was also hired to work in a day program, something that I loved, but which unfortunately had a reputation within the company of being the place people got sent to get fired, so needless to say morale was very low... Soon after I started working management instituted regular meetings where they flew in a highly paid (think $400/hr) lawyer from Chicago to say basically anything up to the legal limit that would slander the union and scare the employees present into thinking they would lose their jobs if they voted to unionize. After the first one of these I requested to be excused from attending any others so that I could focus on working with clients instead, and was initially was told yes, then later told no, I was required to attend. These meetings were labelled as "mandatory trainings" which meant I was forced to attend and listen to them lie and manipulate workers, many of whom had little higher education or familiarity with labor laws. Needless to say, the unionization vote failed.

Actual work conditions were pretty poor at my site. There was no schedule for breaks and we were not given a lunch. Clients were present for almost the entire work day which meant you had to eat with them (legal in my state, if questionable) and could only take a break if your coworkers agreed to cover for you. So, you were basically at the mercy of others to be kind and allow you a break, if it was even possible. The staffing ratio frequently made it impossible. It was common for me to spend 2-3 hours straight on my feet leading activities, making food and feeding clients, changing clients in the bathroom, and chasing other clients around who needed far more behavioral support than we had the staffing to give them, only to get a talking to after some other staff walked through the day program area and saw me sitting down for 2 minutes.

The culture of the workplace (beyond the fight over unionization) was extremely fear-based. During my first yearly review as a DSP I was told I had failed to meet goals that had apparently been set for me but I wasn't told about until I was being reviewed for them! Conversely, everything I had accomplished was ignored or downplayed. Since raises were based on a points system, I ended up with something like an 8 cent per hour raise because I failed to meet all of those mystery "goals".

Working on the residential side was slightly less stressful as management was not there constantly breathing down your neck, but more depressing. The house I worked in the most served clients in wheelchairs who were often parked in front of the television for hours on end, with staff making little effort to offer outings or enriching activities.

Treatment was slightly better when I transitioned to working as a Job Coach, but again, pay was low compared to the other employers in the area, and morale was low. The only real perk was getting to work with clients 1 on 1, instead of having a crazy staffing ratio like 5 or 6 to 1, and being away from the constant micromanaging from management. When I finally left Bethesda I felt guilty for months over leaving my clients and decent coworkers behind, it was that toxic of a culture.
